case_name: Durgadas Shirali v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 95 of 1965 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 95 of 1965. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Petition seeks writ of habeas corpus for release from detention under order by District Magistrate of Bhilwara under Rule 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: K. Garg, M. K. Ramamurthi, S. C. Agarwal and D. P. Singh, for the petitioner. S. Kasliwal, Advocate-General, Rajasthan and R. N. Sachthey, for respondent number 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J. In this case the petitioner-Durgadas Shirali has obtained a rule calling upon the respondents to show cause why a writ of habeas companypus should number be issued under Art. 32 of the Constitution directing his release from detention under an order passed by the District Magistrate of Bhilwara, Rajasthan under Rule 30 1   b  of the Defence of India Rules.

facts.text: Petitioner Durgadas Shirali arrested on January 2, 1965 at Jaipur pursuant to detention order dated December 29, 1964 by Respondent No. 3, Shri Narayan Das Mehta, District Magistrate of Bhilwara.

anchor.surface_text: Cause has be shown by the Advocate-General of Rajasthan on behalf of the respondents to whom numberice of the rule was ordered to be given. The petitioner was arrested on January 2, 1965 at Jaipur in Pursuance of an order dated December 29, 1964 made by res- Pondent number 3, Shri Narayan Das Mehta, District Magistrate of Bhilwara which states as follows It is reliably brought to my numberice that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party has been carrying on antinational and pro-Chinese propaganda and are preparing to act as Pekings member.

facts.text: Detention order directs Superintendent of Police, Bhilwara to arrest and detain Shri Durgadas Shirali in Bhilwara Jail until further orders.

anchor.surface_text: I, Narayan Das Mehta, District Magistrate, Bhilwara in exercise of the powers delegated to me under rule 30 1  clause  b  of the Defence of India Rules 1962 vide Government of Rajasthan Notification No.1 F. 7/1 16 Home A.Cr. 1 63 dated the 4th November, 1963 and all other powers enabling in that behalf direct the Superintendent of Police, Bhilwara that Shri Durga Das Shirali be arrested and detained in the Bhilwara Jail until further orders.

facts.text: Powers delegated to District Magistrate under Rule 30(1)(b) Defence of India Rules 1962 by Government of Rajasthan Notification No.1 F. 7/1 16 Home A.Cr. 1 63 dated November 4, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: I, Narayan Das Mehta, District Magistrate, Bhilwara in exercise of the powers delegated to me under rule 30 1  clause  b  of the Defence of India Rules 1962 vide Government of Rajasthan Notification No.1 F. 7/1 16 Home A.Cr. 1 63 dated the 4th November, 1963 and all other powers enabling in that behalf direct the Superintendent of Police, Bhilwara that Shri Durga Das Shirali be arrested and detained in the Bhilwara Jail until further orders.

facts.text: On January 13, 1965, detention order reviewed by Reviewing Authority who recommended confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: On January 13, 1965 the orders of the District Magistrate was reviewed by the Reviewing Authority who recommended that the detention order dated December 29, 1964 should be companyfirmed.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order by order No. F7/1 19 Home A-Cr. I /65 dated January 22, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companyfirmed the detention order by its order No. F7/1 19 Home A-Cr.  I /65 dated January 22, 1965.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that District Magistrate did not apply mind to specific activities and there was complete absence of material suggesting prejudicial conduct.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the petitioner it was companytended by Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate had number applied his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and there was companyplete absence of material before the District Magistrate to suggest that the companyduct of the petitioner would be prejudicial to the Defence of India and Civil Defence, Indias relations with foreign powers, public safety and the maintenance of the public order.

facts.text: Petitioner contended detention order was mala fide and illegal.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, submitted on behalf of the appellant that the order of detention made by the District Magistrate was mala fide and illegal.

facts.text: One ground in detention order: petitioner is Secretary of Leftist Wing of Communist Party at Bhilwara.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg submitted, in the second place, that one of the grounds mentioned in the order of detention was that the petitioner was a member of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India and Secretary of the local branch of that party at Bhilwara.

facts.text: Leftist wing of Communist Party carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda, preparing for agitation to establish communist regime by subversion and violence.

anchor.surface_text: It is reliably brought to my numberice that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party has been carrying on antinational and pro-Chinese propaganda and are preparing to act as Pekings member. The party having been formed at Pekings behest are preparing for widespread agitation with the object of establishing companymunist regime by subversion and violence.

facts.text: District Magistrate satisfied Shri Durgadas Shirali likely to act prejudicial to Defence of India, Civil Defence, India's relations with foreign powers, public safety, maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: I am also satisfied from the report that Shri Durgadas Shirali of Bhilwara is the Secretary of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party and he is likely to act in manner which is prejudicial to the Defence of India and Civil Defence, Indias relations with Foreign powers, public safety and the maintenance of the public order.

facts.text: Petitioner contended Leftist Communist Party not declared illegal or banned by Government of India, so membership not relevant ground for detention.

anchor.surface_text: The Leftist Communist Party has been carrying on antinational and pro-Chinese propaganda and the District Magistrate was of the opinion that the Leftist Communist Party, therefore, companystituted a real danger to external and internal security of the companyntry. It was submitted by Mr. Garg that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party had number been declared illegal or banned by the Government of India and the membership of the petitioner of the Leftist Communist Party of India was, therefore, number a relevant ground for the order of detention.

facts.text: Proclamation of Emergency issued by President on October 26, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to deal with these points raised on behalf of the petitioner it is necessary to state that in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1  this Court had occasion to companysider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962

facts.text: Presidential Orders dated November 3, 1962 and November 11, 1962 under Article 359(1).

anchor.surface_text: and two orders of the President-one dated November 3, 1962 and the other dated November 11, 1962 issued in exercise of the powers companyferred by cl.  1  of Art. 359 of the Constitution.

facts.text: District Magistrate filed affidavit stating satisfied from reports that petitioner carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda as member of Leftist Wing.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to the petition of the detenu the District Magistrate, Bhilwara has filed an affidavit in this Court. In paragraph 3 of the a davit the District Magistrate has stated that he was satisfied from the reports -that the petitioner was carrying on anti-national and pro Chinese propaganda as a member of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party.

facts.text: District Magistrate's affidavit paragraph 5: passed order after satisfying himself on reports that petitioner was Secretary of Leftist Wing Bhilwara branch and likely to act prejudicially.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 5 the District Magistrate has stated that he passed the order of detention after satisfying himself on the reports that the petitioner was the Secretary of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India, Bhilwara branch and that he was likely to act in a manner prejudicial to Defence of India and Civil Defence, Indias relations with foreign powers, public safety and the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Court holds District Magistrate applied mind to specific activities of petitioner based on affidavit, rejects petitioner's argument.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the affidavit of the District Magistrate it is number possible for us to accept the argument of Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate did number apply his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and that he made the order of detention solely on the ground that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India was carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda.

facts.text: Leftist wing of Communist Party not declared illegal by Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued on behalf of the petitioner that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India has number been declared illegal by the Government of India and the party has number been banned.

facts.text: Court rejects argument that membership in Leftist wing irrelevant for detention under Rule 30 as political association is relevant consideration.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the light of the reports received by the District Magistrate the political association of the petitioner and his membership of a particular political group is a relevant companysideration in the matter of detention of the petitioner. This ground has close and proximate companynection with the security of State and maintenance of public order as companytemplated by Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules.

facts.text: Court holds petitioner has not made out case for writ under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the petitioner has number made .out a case for the grant of a writ under Art.
Art. 32 of the Constitution of India
Art. 32 of the Constitution directing his release from detention under an order passed by the District Magistrate of Bhilwara, Rajasthan under Rule 30 1   b  of the Defence of India Rules.

issues.text: Whether the validity of the detention order can be challenged on grounds other than contravention of Articles 14, 19, 21 and 22 during the pendency of Presidential Order under Article 359(1), such as mala fides or irrelevant grounds?

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to deal with these points raised on behalf of the petitioner it is necessary to state that in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1  this Court had occasion to consi

issues.text: Whether the order of detention is bad because the District Magistrate had not applied his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner?

anchor.surface_text: It is contended, in the first place, on behalf of the petitioner, that the order of detention is bad because the District Magistrate had number applied his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner. It was pointed out that in the order of detention the District Magistrate has mainly dealt with the activities of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India which was carrying on antinational and pro-Chinese propaganda.

issues.text: Whether the ground that the petitioner was the Secretary of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India was irrelevant for the purpose of Rule 30(1)(b) of the Defence of India Rules, such that the order of detention as a whole is vitiated?

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued on behalf of the petitioner that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India has number been declared illegal by the Government of India and the party has number been banned. It was submitted, therefore, that membership of that party was number per se illegal and the order of detention of the petitioner cannot be legally based upon this ground. In other words, it was submitted by Mr. Garg that the ground. that the petitioner was the Secretary of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India was irrelevant for the purpose of Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules. The argument was put forward that if this ground was irrelevant for the purpose of the Rule or was wholly illusory, the order of detention as a whole was vitiated

issues.text: Whether the petitioner has made out a case for the grant of a writ of habeas corpus under Article 32 of the Constitution?

holdings.text: A challenge to the detention order on grounds other than contravention of Articles 14, 19, 21 and 22, such as mala fides or irrelevant grounds lacking real and proximate connection, is permissible despite the Presidential Order under Article 359(1).

anchor.surface_text: real and proximate connection between the ground given and the object which the legislature has in view. It is contended, in the first place, on behalf of the petitioner, that the order of detention is bad because the District Magistrate had not applied his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner. It was pointed out that in the order of detention the District Magistrate has mainly dealt with the activities of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India which was carrying on antinational and pro-Chinese propaganda.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab, Presidential Orders under Art. 359 bar only specified fundamental rights claims; other grounds like mala fides or irrelevant grounds remain challengeable.

holdings.text: The District Magistrate applied his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and the order of detention is not vitiated for non-application of mind or mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the affidavit of the District Magistrate it is number possible for us to accept the argument of Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate did number apply his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and that he made the order of detention solely on the ground that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India was carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda.

holdings.reasoning_summary: District Magistrate's affidavit (paras 3 and 5) confirms satisfaction based on reports of petitioner's specific anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda as member and Secretary of Leftist Wing, likely to act prejudicially.

holdings.text: Membership and position as Secretary of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party is a relevant ground for detention under Rule 30(1)(b) as it has close and proximate connection with security of State and public order; not irrelevant merely because the party is not banned.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the light of the reports received by the District Magistrate the political association of the petitioner and his membership of a particular political group is a relevant companysideration in the matter of detention of the petitioner. This ground has close and proximate companynection with the security of State and maintenance of public order as companytemplated by Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing Shibban Lal Saksena; District Magistrate can consider political associations, loyalties, and reports of group's pro-Chinese propaganda and preparations for subversion despite no ban; satisfies rational nexus test under Rule 30.

holdings.text: The petitioner has not made out a case for the grant of a writ of habeas corpus under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the petitioner has number made .out a case for the grant of a writ under Art.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All petitioner contentions rejected: application of mind confirmed by affidavit; membership ground relevant with nexus to Rule 30 objectives.

precedents.citation: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1  this Court had occasion to companysider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962 and two orders of the President-one dated November 3, 1962 and the other dated November 11, 1962 issued in exercise of the powers companyferred by cl.  1  of Art. 359 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: sweep of Art. 359(1) and Presidential Orders thereunder bars challenges to detention orders based on violation of Arts. 14, 19, 21, 22 during emergency but permits challenges on other grounds like mala fides or irrelevant grounds
precedents.cited_holding: the validity of the Ordinance or any rule or order made thereunder cannot be questioned on the ground that it contravenes Arts. 14, 21 and 22 but can be challenged on other grounds; detention can be challenged for mala fides or irrelevant grounds

precedents.citation: Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of Uttar Pradesh ,- .

anchor.surface_text: Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of Uttar Pradesh ,- . We are unable to accept the argument of Mr. Garg as companyrect. It is number companyrect to state that the activities of the Leftist wing of the Communist Party cannot in any circumstances be illegal and would necessarily be irrelevant merely because the Government of India has number declared the party illegal or imposed a ban.

precedents.case_name: Shibban Lal Saksena v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: if any ground for detention is irrelevant or illusory, the entire detention order is vitiated
